snippet: In the debate matching chain stores, banks and pharmacies vs. quirky one-of-a-kind shops, city officials and West Siders ponder what this plan may mean to “the soul of the neighborhood.”
abstract: New York City planning officials propose an amendment to the zoning laws for Manhattan's Upper West Side that would limit the ground-floor width of new stores to 40 feet on certain streets, and 25 feet for banks; intention is to slow the proliferation of large chain stores and preserve the neighborhood's commercial character and vibrant street life; supporters hope the plan could serve as a blueprint for other neighborhoods fighting to maintain space for small stores and local shopkeepers.
lead_paragraph: In the debate matching chain stores, banks and pharmacies vs. quirky one-of-a-kind shops, city officials and West Siders ponder what this plan may mean to “the soul of the neighborhood.”

headline.seo: Zoning Proposal on Upper West Side Could Reshape Commerce
headline.main: Retail Limits in Plan for the Upper West Side
headline.print_headline: Retail Limits in Plan for the Upper West Side
